Content: I second Emacswiki as suggested, but I find quite a bit by searching through the Emacs and Elisp info pages and using M-x apropos / M-x apropos-variable. It doesn't always work though - to find something, you generally need to know what Emacs calls it.

Author: agentbleu
Title: ASK HN: Generic backend interface for web apps
Content: I'm wondering if anyone knows of a generic backend interface for web apps. Sure we could be lazy and just use phpmyadmin for playing with simple apps that we can't be bothered to build a backend for. But is there a generic product that can be intelligently incorporated without too much hassle.

Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
Funny, I really don't feel bad for people who break into other people's accounts and steal their information.

Whom I feel bad for is all the regular folks that had the same thing happen and are not running for office.

Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
I'm outsourcing to South America and I've been using PayPal.

There were a few other options, as I recall. A service called Payoneer, some others.

It used to be W.U. exclusively, but that's changed in the last ten years.

Content: Still the only way that millions of poor people working in rich countries have to send money home.  If I recall correctly, at least.

Author: thwarted
Content:
I don't know about the lisp code (where you use \w), but \\w matches a backslash and a w, as the first \ escapes the second. I wasn't saying you were using PHP, but I know the PHP docs were confusing on how to escape things because backslash is overloaded for string escaping and for regular expression escaping and character classes.

I can't see how a more complete (complex?) correct regular expression would produce MORE noise in your output. The very fact that you allow the empty string on the LHS means that you risk getting invalid addresses.

Continue to use that busted regular expression for parsing email addresses out of these 30,000 HTML files and please remove all my email addresses from the list you generate while you're at it.
